title: Rangers banking on Yovani Gallardo to stifle Blue Jays bats
text:
TORONTO - 
Texas was feeling great when it acquired hometown hero Yovani Gallardo last January. 
He was supposed to slot in as an excellent No. 3 or No. 4 starter behind Yu Darvish and Derek Holland. 
Three months later, Darvish was done for the year, Holland for four months and Gallardo was suddenly sharing ace duties with Colby Lewis. 
Now, with true ace Cole Hamels, who was acquired later, slated for Game 2, Gallardo will be asked again to step to the fore against the Blue Jays. 
Gallardo, 13-11 with a 3.42 ERA this season, beat the Jays twice this season — the only wins in six tries against Toronto for the Rangers this year. 
The Jays mustered only six hits in Gallardo’s 13.2 scoreless innings. 
The key, Gallardo said, was challenging the Jays’ potent hitters and mixing up the location of his pitches well. 
“We came up with a good game plan, just being aggressive,” Gallardo said Wednesday of the earlier meetings. 
“They have a powerful lineup with what they did throughout the year. With the catchers, we did a good job of making adjustments throughout the game whenever we had to. Just being aggressive in the zone and getting the guys to swing the bat. 
“It’s a matter of executing pitches, hitting your spots and putting it where you want to throw it. Going into those games, I had faced a lot of those guys during my career. It’s just moving the ball around. Being aggressive in the zone throwing strikes.” 
Toronto has a lineup stacked with right-handed pitchers that punish lefties, which is part of the reason why the big righty drew the opening start. 
“He’s just got good pitches that break away from the big righty bats,” Texas closer Shawn Tolleson said in trying to explain Gallardo’s earlier success. 
“He’s got a deceptive angle for them. He’s got a good overhand curveball and a cutter and it keeps them off-balance.” 
At times, Gallardo can get himself into trouble by walking too many batters, but Texas manager Jeff Banister said the righty’s ability to keep hitters guessing is also a major strength. 
“He works around the edges, he throws just enough strikes to get you in swing mode and then he can go inside on you. Or he can go away and he can also work the vertical game as well,” Banister said. 
“The one thing that you can’t do really, is sit on any one pitch.” 
Gallardo also has experience on his side, having pitched in five previous playoff games, all with Milwaukee. 
But this is a new honour for him. 
“Not very many get this opportunity to pitch Game 1 of the post-season for a team they grew up watching,” he said. 
“I’m from Fort Worth. I lived there all my life. To put that uniform on and start Game 1, it’s going to be a lot of excitement and adrenalin going on.” 
THE USUAL 
Gallardo’s counterpart on the hill Thursday will be David Price. 
Prince Fielder was asked what makes Price so tough to hit against. 
“You know, he throws 98 (miles per hour), a couple of off-speed pitches, he hits his spots. You know, the usual Cy Young stuff,” Fielder said. 
Price will be in the running for another Cy Young Award this season, thanks to his 18-5 record (9-1 with the Blue Jays) and American League-leading 2.45 ERA. 
“He doesn’t mess around too much,” said Josh Hamilton. 
“He’s not afraid of contact. That can be good for you sometimes, or not ... He’s a tough pitcher, you want to do your best to make him work extra hard on the mound. Get some guys on base, cause a little havoc, grind out at-bats.” 
NO OVER-THINKING 
The experienced players and managers all had a similar message ahead of Game 1: Don’t get too worked up about playing in the post-season. 
“We’ll treat this game just like all the rest of them. It’s one game, one game at a time,” Banister said. 
“It’s a statement (Pirates manager Clint Hurdle) says all the time: ‘The game doesn’t know that the game is important.’ It really doesn’t, it’s still a game. You go out and meet the demands of the game.” 
Price told his teammates: “Don’t let it change you. Go out there and do the same stuff you always do. Post-season baseball is definitely different, but you’ve got to go out there and treat it the same. If you get caught up that this is the playoffs, you can kind of get overwhelmed with it.” 
AROUND THE HORN 
Young Rangers standout second baseman Rougned Odor keeps a creepy-looking mask in his locker. Kind of an old, mad scientist-looking thing. Why? “I just take it everywhere,” Odor said. “It’s called the Old Man” ... Centre fielder Delino DeShields is battling the flu, but says he will play ... Gallardo on playing in a city that has experienced a long playoff drought like Toronto: “I had the opportunity to participate in the post-season in Milwaukee in 2008 (ending a span of 26 years without a post-season berth for the franchise). It’s going to be electric. I think the fans will be on every pitch. It’s going to be pretty loud in here,” Gallardo said. “The fans are excited, the players are excited. The whole country. I think it’s going to be one of the things that everyone is going to be watching. It’s going to be a fun series.” Sponsored Links
